name: Bulgaria
partner: Central European Institute of Asian Studies (CEIAS)
takeaway: There has been a notable increase in joint Bulgarian-Chinese media activities, exchange of journalistic delegations and growth in China-favorable reporting.

China has accelerated its 'soft power' offensive in Bulgarian society through cultural events, particularly spearheaded by its diplomatic representation. TikTok has palpably increased its presence and populuarity among Bulgarian users since the last edition of the Index.

There are indications that some modest alterations are taking place in Bulgarian foreign policy towards greater engagement with Taiwan, although the clear conceptual underpinnings of such engagement and practical effects are still to follow. At the same time, on the party political level, the far right represented by the Revival party has more frequently interacted with Chinese diplomatic officials and promoted pro-Beijing talking points.
Overall, the overarching trend of limited Chinese economic presence in Bulgaria and absence of defense cooperation has persisted, all the while Beijing's media amd cultural reach has expanded.
description-1: In 2023, Bulgaria had a GDP per capita of US$15,798 and a total population of 6.81 million people.
description-2: Bulgaria established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 2049. Bulgaria was ranked 59th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 78/100.
